attributes.description: Choose whether to allow users to add, modify, and delete camera presets. If allowed, they can edit presets from the Manual camera controls panel in the user interface.

description.Auto: Users can add, modify, and delete camera presets.
description.Locked: The camera presets are locked. Users can use the presets, but not add, delete, or modify them.

attributes.description: Choose which type of contact information to show on the user interface.

description.Auto: Show the address which another device should dial to reach this video device. The address depends on the default call protocol and device registration.
description.DisplayName: Show the device's display name (refer to the SIP DisplayName setting).
description.E164Alias: Show the device's H.323 E164 Alias as contact information (refer to the H323 H323Alias E164 setting).
description.H323Id: Show the device's H.323 ID (refer to the H323 H323Alias ID setting).
description.None: Do not show any contact information.
description.SipUri: Show the device's SIP URI (refer to the SIP URI setting).
description.SystemName: Show the device's name (refer to the SystemUnit Name setting).
description.WebexDisplayName: The name of a user or device as it appears within the Cisco Webex cloud service.

attributes.description: Choose which type of contact information to show on the user interface.

description.Auto: Show the address which another device should dial to reach this video device. The address depends on the default call protocol and device registration.
description.None: Do not show any contact information.
description.SipUri: Show the device's SIP URI (refer to the SIP URI setting).
description.SystemName: Show the device's name (refer to the SystemUnit Name setting).
description.WebexDisplayName: The name of a user or device as it appears within the Cisco Webex cloud service.

attributes.description: A custom message can be displayed, in the lower left side of the screen, in awake mode.
When using a custom wallpaper you can choose to apply a transparent black overlay to soften the background image and give more focus to the UI elements.

description.Off: Don't apply a transparent black overlay.
description.On: Apply a transparent black overlay.

attributes.description: Enables the winter/seasonal theme during the month of December only.

description.Off: Disables the theme.
description.On: Enables the theme.

attributes.description: This is a notification that appears in the top right corner of devices set up with hot desking. It allows users to sign into the device via QR code.

description.Off: the notification is off.
description.On: the notification is on.

attributes.description: Hide or show diagnostics notifications on the user interface.

description.Auto: The diagnostics notifications will be displayed on the user interface.
description.Hidden: The diagnostics notifications will not be displayed on the user interface.

attributes.description: Choose whether to show the calendar widget on the user interface.

description.Auto: Show the calendar widget on the user interface.
description.Hidden: Don't show the calendar widget on the user interface.

attributes.description: Choose to show or hide the default "Mute/Unmute" button on the user interface.

description.Auto: Show the "Mute/Unmute" button on the user interface.
description.Hidden: The "Mute/Unmute" button is not shown on the user interface.

attributes.description: Choose to show or hide the camera controls from the user interface (control panel). The setting applies both in-call and out of call.

description.Auto: Shows the camera controls on the user interface.
description.Hidden: Removes the camera controls from the user interface.

attributes.description: Choose whether or not to remove the default End Call button from the user interface. The setting removes only the button, not its functionality as such.

description.Auto: Shows the button on the user interface.
description.Hidden: Removes the button from the user interface.

attributes.description: Choose whether to show the Call from laptop button on the touch controller. Refer to the Video Output HDMI Passthrough Allowed setting for more information about HDMI passthrough and the Call from laptop feature. Call from laptop is not supported on Room 55 Dual and Room 70 Dual.

description.Auto: Show the button on the touch controller.
description.Hidden: Don't show the button on the touch controller.

attributes.description: Choose to show or hide the Google Meet button on the user interface. The button allows users to dial into Google Meet meetings using the meeting code generated by the Google invite. This is only available on devices registered to the Webex cloud service or linked to Webex Edge for devices.

description.Auto: Show the button on the user interface.
description.Hidden: Don't show the button from the user interface.

attributes.description: Configures whether to display or hide the CVI (Microsoft Cloud Video Interop) functionality on the Microsoft Teams button in the user interface. When enabled, users can use the Microsoft Teams button to join Teams meetings via CVI by entering the Video Conference ID and passcode from the meeting invite. If disabled, the Microsoft Teams button still appears, but the CVI-specific input screen for Video ID is hidden. This feature is available only on devices registered to the Webex cloud service or connected through Webex Edge for Devices.

description.Auto: Shows the CVI functionality on the Microsoft Teams button where users can enter the Video ID.
description.Hidden: Doesn't show the CVI functionality on the Microsoft Teams button.

attributes.description: Configures whether to display or hide the Direct Guest Join functionality on the Microsoft Teams button in the user interface. When enabled, users can use the Microsoft Teams button to join Teams meetings via Direct Guest Join by entering the Meeting ID from the invite. If disabled, the Microsoft Teams button still appears, but the input screen for entering the Meeting ID is hidden. This feature is available only on devices registered to the Webex cloud service or connected through Webex Edge for Devices.

description.Auto: Displays the Direct Guest Join functionality where users can enter the Meeting ID.

attributes.description: Choose to show or hide the default Webex button on the user interface. The button allows users to dial into a Webex meeting using the Webex meeting number, no domain is required. However, for this to work, you must set up the infrastructure to allow calls to be routed to *@webex.com.

description.Auto: Shows the button on the user interface.
description.Hidden: Removes the button from the user interface.

attributes.description: Choose to show or hide the Zoom button on the user interface. The button allows users to dial into Zoom meetings using the meeting code generated by the Zoom invite.

description.Auto: Shows the button on the user interface.
description.Hidden: Removes the button from the user interface.

attributes.description: Choose whether or not to remove the default in-call Keypad button from the user interface. This button opens a keypad, which for example can be used for DTMF input.

description.Auto: Shows the button on the user interface.
description.Hidden: Removes the button from the user interface.

attributes.description: Choose whether to show the Layout button, which by default is available in call, on the user interface.

description.Auto: Show the button on the user interface.
description.Hidden: Don't show the button on the user interface.

attributes.description: Choose to show or hide buttons for most mid-call options from the user interface, for example Hold, Transfer, and Resume. The setting removes only the buttons, not their functionality as such.

description.Auto: Shows the buttons on the user interface.
description.Hidden: Removes the buttons from the user interface.

attributes.description: Choose to show or hide the toggle button for Music Mode on the user interface.

description.Auto: Shows the toggle button for Music Mode on the user interface if this feature is supported in the ongoing call.
description.Hidden: The toggle button for Music Mode is never shown on the user interface.

attributes.description: Choose whether to show the Participants button, which by default is available in call, on the user interface.

description.Auto: Show the button on the user interface.
description.Hidden: Don't show the button on the user interface.

attributes.description: Choose whether to show the self-view controls on the user interface.

description.Auto: Show the self-view controls on the user interface.
description.Hidden: Don't show the self-view controls on the user interface.

attributes.description: Choose to show or hide the default Call button (including the directory, favorites, and recent calls lists) and the default in-call Add participant button on the user interface. The setting removes only the buttons, not their functionality as such.

description.Auto: Shows the buttons on the user interface.
description.Hidden: Removes the buttons from the user interface.

attributes.description: Choose to show or hide the default "Turn video off" button on the user interface.

description.Auto: Shows the "Turn video off" button on the user interface if this feature is supported in the ongoing call.
description.Hidden: The "Turn video off" button is never shown on the user interface.

attributes.description: Choose whether to show the Call from laptop button on the touch controller.

description.Auto: Show the button on the touch controller.
description.Hidden: Don't show the button on the touch controller.

attributes.description: Choose whether to remove the default Files button from the user interface. The Files button is available only on devices with a touch screen (either built-in or connected). A Room Kit Mini must be used with Samsung Flip (Webex on Flip). The setting removes only the button, not its functionality as such. This setting applies only to devices that are registered to the Webex cloud service or linked to Webex Edge for Devices.

description.Auto: Shows the button on the user interface.
description.Hidden: Removes the button from the user interface.

attributes.description: Choose to hide all the buttons on the user interface. The setting removes only the buttons, not their functionality.

description.False: Shows all default buttons on the user interface.
description.True: Removes all default buttons from the user interface.

attributes.description: Allows users to turn off the auto source selection for Microsoft Teams Rooms (MTR) calls.

description.Off: Turn off the auto source selection for Microsoft Teams Rooms (MTR) calls.
description.On: Turn on the auto source selection for Microsoft Teams Rooms (MTR) calls.

attributes.description: This configuration allows toggling between Microsoft Teams Rooms (MTR) and RoomOS share experiences on devices in MTR mode.

description.Microsoft: The sharing experience is fully managed by the MTR application. Previews are initiated and displayed within the Microsoft Teams Rooms app, following its standard behavior and interface.
description.RoomOS: The sharing experience is managed by Webex RoomOS. Previews are initiated by Webex and overlaid on the screen. RoomOS provides enhanced functionality, including support for multi-source sharing, multi-screen configurations, and 4K resolution.

attributes.description: Choose whether or not to remove the default UI elements for sharing and previewing content, both in call and out of call, from the user interface. The setting removes only the buttons and UI elements, not their functionality as such. You can still share content using Cisco Proximity or Cisco Webex apps.

description.Auto: Shows the buttons and UI elements on the user interface.
description.Hidden: Removes the buttons and UI elements from the user interface.

attributes.description: Choose whether to remove the default Whiteboard button from the user interface. The Whiteboard button is available only on devices with a touch screen (either built-in or connected). A Room Kit Mini must be used with Samsung Flip (Webex on Flip). The setting removes only the button, not its functionality as such. This setting applies only to devices that are registered to the Webex cloud service or linked to Webex Edge for Devices.

description.Auto: Shows the button on the user interface.
description.Hidden: Removes the button from the user interface.

attributes.description: Help tips can be accessed through the user interface. When enabled, a Tips button is present on the home screen.

description.Auto: Show the help tips button.
description.Hidden: Hide the help tips button.

attributes.description: Choose whether to remove elements, such as the clock and meeting list, from the home screen.

description.Off: Remove home screen elements.
description.On: Keep all home screen elements.

attributes.description: Choose whether to remove elements, such as the clock and meeting list, from the home screen.

description.On: Keep all home screen elements.

attributes.description: Only when the AllowInsecureHttps setting is enabled (set to True) in this configuration, and the host has been explicitly added to the allow-list using the WebEngine AllowInsecureHttps Add command, will the web page presenting a self-signed certificate be displayed.

Set the URL of the web application you want to run on the Room Navigator (that is, a persistent web app). The application displays on the entire screen, and it can't be dismissed by the user. If the app is going to interact with the device's API, remember to set Security Xapi WebSocket ApiKey Allowed: True, and add the domain name of the server hosting the app to the allow list in the WebEngine Features Xapi Peripherals AllowedHosts Hosts setting. Note: Persistent web apps are only available on Room Navigators that are paired to the device over the network.
Decide how the add participant (invite people) capability will be shown on the device when starting an instant meeting.

description.ManualAdd: The add/invite capability doesn't show up on the screen automatically. You must use the usual Add button on the UI.
description.Promote: The add/invite capability shows up on the screen automatically when you start the meeting.

attributes.description: You can configure the device to make a keyboard click sound effect (key tone) when typing text or numbers.

description.Off: There is no key tone sound effect.
description.On: The key tone sound effect is turned on.

attributes.description: You can configure the device to make a keyboard click sound effect (key tone) when typing text or numbers.

description.Off: There is no key tone sound effect.
description.On: The key tone sound effect is turned on.

attributes.description: You can configure the device to make a keyboard click sound effect (key tone) when typing text or numbers.

description.Off: There is no key tone sound effect.
description.On: The key tone sound effect is turned on.

attributes.description: Kiosk mode lets you replace the home screen of the device with your own custom web application that you host and maintain yourself. The URL to the custom web application must be added in the UserInterface Kiosk URL setting. As an example, Kiosk mode can be used in reception areas where you want the device set up for visitor registration, providing the facility overview, or allow direct calls to expert services. Kiosk mode is using the device's web engine, so the WebEngine Mode setting must be On for kiosk mode to work. To allow for making calls, the WebEngine Features SipUrlHandler setting must be On as well.

description.Off: The device operates in standard mode.
description.On: The device is set up in kiosk mode.

attributes.description: The URL of the custom web application that is shown when the device is set up in kiosk mode. Also refer to the UserInterface Kiosk Mode setting.
Select the language to be used on the user interface. If the language is not supported, the default language (English) will be used.
The wall mount version of the Room Navigator has LED lights. You can configure how they should be controlled.

description.Auto: The video device controls the LED lights automatically, typically based on the room booking status (for example, green: room available, red: room in use). The UserInterface LedControl Color Set Color command will have no effect.
description.Manual: You can control the LED lights and set the color using the UserInterface LedControl Color Set Color command.
description.Off: The LED lights are turned off permanently.

attributes.description: Controls the behavior of the LED strip during non-office hours when the display enters standby mode. By default, the LED strip remains active to indicate room occupancy, even when the display is turned off.

description.Off: The LED strip is disabled when the display enters standby mode during non-office hours.
description.On: The LED strip remains active to indicate occupancy, even when the display is off.

attributes.description: Allows presenters to annotate on the screen share in a meeting without any interruption to the content share flow. This feature only applies if you have a touch screen. Collaborative annotation on a whiteboard shared by someone else is only available for Webex (converged) meetings, and only for devices that are registered to the Webex cloud service or linked to Webex Edge for devices.

description.Always: Live annotation is always available for presenters.
description.MultiPlayerSupportedByCall: Live Annotation is enabled only in calls that support multi-participant (or two-way) annotation, allowing presenters to annotate on shared content collaborativelyâ€”whether on their own share or others' shared content. This does not apply to one-on-one calls.

attributes.description: The live annotation feature allows users to annotate on the screen share in call or outside call without any interruption to the content share flow. This feature only applies if you have a touch screen. Collaborative annotation on a whiteboard shared by someone else is only available for Webex (converged) meetings, and only for devices that are registered to the Webex cloud service or linked to Webex Edge for devices. Use this setting to determine whether you are allowed to annotate live on the content.

description.False: You cannot make live annotation. The annotation button in the floating toolbar doesn't have the "Point and annotate on content" option. The "Annotate on screenshot" option is not affected by this setting.
description.True: You can make live annotation. Start by tapping the annotation button in the floating toolbar, then select the "Point and annotate on content" option.

attributes.description: The live annotation feature allows users to annotate on the screen share in call or outside call without any interruption to the content share flow. This feature only applies if you have a touch screen. Collaborative annotation on a whiteboard shared by someone else is only available for Webex (converged) meetings, and only for devices that are registered to the Webex cloud service or linked to Webex Edge for devices. Use this setting to determine whether you are allowed to annotate live on the content.

description.False: You cannot make live annotation. The annotation button in the floating toolbar doesn't have the "Point and annotate on content" option. The "Annotate on screenshot" option is not affected by this setting.
description.True: You can make live annotation. Start by tapping the annotation button in the floating toolbar, then select the "Point and annotate on content" option.

attributes.description: Use this setting to determine whether you are allowed to annotate live on the content outside of a call. This feature only applies if you have a touch screen. Collaborative annotation on a whiteboard shared by someone else is only available for Webex (converged) meetings, and only for devices that are registered to the Webex cloud service or linked to Webex Edge for devices.

description.False: You cannot make live annotation outside a call.
description.True: You can make live annotation during a call.

attributes.description: Set the default hostname/tenant key to be used for Microsoft Teams meetings when the device is set up to use CVI (Cloud Video Interop). This hostname, which identifies the organization hosting the meeting, is combined with the video conference ID to generate the full SIP URI for the meeting. In the following examples, the video conference ID is 123456. If UserInterface MeetingJoin CVITenants is set to "tenant@m.webex.com", the URI becomes 123456.tenant@m.webex.com. If UserInterface MeetingJoin CVITenants is set to "vc.example.com", the URI becomes 123456@vc.example.com.
Choose whether to show a warning on screen if you start talking while your microphone is muted.

description.Disabled: Don't show the mute warning.
description.Enabled: Show the mute warning.

attributes.description: You can configure a device to hide all name and site labels for remote participants in a meeting.

description.Auto: Show name and site labels.
description.Hidden: Hide name and site labels.

attributes.description: Define whether to show a "Call encrypted" / "Call not encrypted" notification on screen at the start of a meeting. Regardless of this setting, you can always find information about encryption under Security (blue shield) when tapping the screen (upper right corner) or touch controller (upper). This setting doesn't apply to Webex and WebRTC calls.

description.AlwaysOff: The "Call encrypted" / "Call not encrypted" notification will not be shown on screen at all.
description.AlwaysOn: If the call is encrypted, the "Call encrypted" notification is shown for 5 seconds. If the call is not encrypted, the "Call not encrypted" notification is shown for 5 seconds.
description.Auto: If the call is encrypted, the "Call encrypted" notification is shown for 5 seconds. If the call is not encrypted, the "Call not encrypted" notification is shown for 5 seconds.

attributes.description: A custom message can be displayed in the middle of the main screen when the device is in the halfwake state. The custom message will replace the default message, which gives instructions how to start using the device. You can also delete the default message, without adding a custom message.

You can configure a device to output a clean video stream. This is referred to as broadcast mode. In this mode the indicators, notifications, and controls are removed. This mode is primarily for broadcasting and recording services where you only want to pass on the video to your viewers.

description.Auto: Indicators, notifications, and controls are included in the video stream (normal mode).
description.Unobstructed: Indicators, notifications, and controls are removed from the video stream (broadcast mode). Name labels are not removed.

attributes.description: Specify the monitor to use for displaying on-screen information and indicators. This is the On-Screen Display (OSD).

description.1: The device sends the on-screen information and indicators to the device's integrated screen.

attributes.description: Specify the monitor to use for displaying on-screen information and indicators. This is the On-Screen Display (OSD).

description.Auto: The device detects when a screen is connected to a video output, and sends the on-screen information and indicators to the first screen you connect. If you have a multi-monitor setup, and all screens are connected before switching on the device, the on-screen information and indicators are sent to the video output with the lowest number, starting with Output Connector 1 (HDMI 1).

attributes.description: Specify the monitor to use for displaying on-screen information and indicators. This is the On-Screen Display (OSD).

description.Auto: The device detects when a screen is connected to a video output, and sends the on-screen information and indicators to the first screen you connect. If you have a multi-screen setup, and all screens are connected before switching on the device, the on-screen information and indicators are sent to the video output with the lowest number, starting with Output Connector 1 (HDMI 1).

attributes.description: When searching for a name in the directory, you can search through everything or filter to include only people or only rooms. This is only available on devices registered to the Webex cloud service or linked to Webex Edge for devices.

description.All: Search results include both people and rooms.

attributes.description: This setting determines if a user is allowed to add or change a contact in the Directory and Favorites list from the user interface of the device.

description.ReadOnly: You cannot add a contact to the Favorites list, edit a contact in the Favorites list, or edit any contact from the Directory or Favorites list before calling.
description.ReadWrite: You are able to add a contact to the Favorites list, edit a contact in the Favorites list, and edit a contact from the Directory or Favorites list before calling.

attributes.description: Configure the display of proximity notifications on the user interface.

description.Auto: Allow the system to automatically determine when to display proximity notifications.
description.Off: Proximity notifications will not be shown on the user interface.
description.On: All proximity notifications will be shown on the user interface.

attributes.description: This setting applies when a Room Navigator is set up as a room booking device (also referred to as scheduler mode). The Room Navigator may show the room temperature, if that is available from the device it's connected to. Use this setting to decide whether to display it.

description.Auto: Show the temperature in both degrees Celsius and Fahrenheit.
description.Hidden: Don't show the temperature.
description.ShowFahrenheit: Show the temperature in degrees Fahrenheit.

attributes.description: Enables the room booking navigator to display a QR code that can be used to sign in from outside the room when hot desking is enabled on a device paired inside the room. This feature facilitates easier user sign-ins for hot desking scenarios.

description.Off: Disables the QR code display on the room booking navigator.
description.On: Enables the QR code display on the room booking navigator, allowing users to sign in from outside the room.

attributes.description: This setting applies when a Room Navigator is set up as a room booking device (also referred to as scheduler mode). Configures the mode of operation for a Room Navigator, determining how the device displays and manages room scheduling information.

description.Auto: Shows both calendar events and room usage status as needed.
description.CalendarOnly: Displays only calendar-based scheduling information, without integrating room usage status.
description.RoomInUseOnly: Displays only the room usage status, without showing calendar events.

attributes.description: This setting applies when a Room Navigator is set up as a room booking device (also referred to as scheduler mode). Configures the mode of operation for a Room Navigator, determining how the device displays and manages room scheduling information.

description.Auto: Shows both calendar events and room usage status as needed.
description.CalendarOnly: Displays only calendar-based scheduling information, without integrating room usage status.
description.RoomInUseOnly: Displays only the room usage status, without showing calendar events.

attributes.description: Allows you to configure the opacity of the top panels of the Room Navigator, which can show or hide more of the background.

This setting applies when a Room Navigator is set up as a room booking device (also referred to as scheduler mode). The Room Navigator may show the number of people currently in the meeting room, if that information is available from the device it's connected to. Use this setting to decide whether to display this information.

description.Auto: Show the number of people.
description.Hidden: Don't show the number of people.

attributes.description: This setting applies when a Room Navigator is set up as a room booking device (also referred to as scheduler mode). You can change the color of the LED strip and the room status icon on Room Navigators. The chosen color is applied to both the LED strip and the room status icon. This setting determines which color to use when the room is available. Use the UserInterface RoomScheduler State Busy Color and UserInterface RoomScheduler State Pending Color settings to choose which colors to use when the room is occupied, or booked without being occupied, respectively.

This setting applies when a Room Navigator is set up as a room booking device (also referred to as scheduler mode). You can change the color of the LED strip and the room status icon on Room Navigators. The chosen color is applied to both the LED strip and the room status icon. This setting determines which color to use when the room is occupied. Use the UserInterface RoomScheduler State Available Color and UserInterface RoomScheduler State Pending Color settings to choose which colors to use when the room is available, or booked without being occupied, respectively.

This setting applies when a Room Navigator is set up as a room booking device (also referred to as scheduler mode). You can change the color of the LED strip and the room status icon on Room Navigators. The chosen color is applied to both the LED strip and the room status icon. This setting determines which color to use when the room is booked without being occupied. Use the UserInterface RoomScheduler State Available Color and UserInterface RoomScheduler State Busy Color settings to choose which colors to use when the room is available or occupied, respectively.
This setting allows you to show or hide the top left menu of the user interface.

description.Auto: The top left menu is visible.
description.Hidden: The top left menu is hidden.

attributes.description: Choose whether to enforce setting a PIN lock on the device. In locked mode, only emergency calls, and reception of important notifications (without revealing details) are available. This setting applies to Board, Desk and Room Series devices in personal mode, and to Desk Series devices in shared mode. The device must be registered to the Webex cloud service or linked to Webex Edge for devices.

description.Enforced: You must set a PIN lock on the device before you can start using it. On shared mode devices, this applies only if the UserInterface ScreenLock Workspace Allowed setting is True.
description.Optional: The users can decide if they want to set a PIN lock on personal devices. On shared mode devices, you can decide to set a PIN lock only if the UserInterface ScreenLock Workspace Allowed setting is True.

attributes.description: Choose whether the user is allowed to add a PIN lock for the device. This setting applies only to shared mode devices, because you are always allowed to add a PIN lock on personal mode devices. Refer to the UserInterface ScreenLock AdminInitiateRecovery command, how to initiate setting PIN lock on a device.

description.False: The user is not allowed to add a PIN lock.
description.True: The user is allowed to add a PIN lock.

attributes.description: This setting allows you to hide the contact information from the top left dropdown menu on the user interface. However, this does not hide any details from the Device settings panel, which you can open from the control panel (swipe from right or tap the icon in the upper right corner of the user interface). Refer to the UserInterface SettingsMenu Mode and UserInterface SettingsMenu Visibility for more information about protecting device settings and hiding information from the user interface.

description.Normal: The contact information is shown in the dropdown menu.
description.Strong: Contact information is not shown in the dropdown menu.

attributes.description: The Device settings panel, which you can open from the control panel (swipe from right or tap the icon in the upper right corner of the user interface), can be protected by the device's admin password. If not password protected, anyone can access these settings and also factory reset the device. If password protected, all settings that require authentication have a padlock symbol. Refer to the UserInterface SettingsMenu Visibility if you want to remove the control panel (including the device settings panel) from the user interface.

description.Locked: You must sign in with an administrator's username and passphrase to access Device settings.
description.Unlocked: All users can access the Device settings.

attributes.description: This setting allows you to remove the control panel (including the device settings panel) from the user interface. Refer to the UserInterface SettingsMenu Mode if you just want to protect the device settings with a password.

description.Auto: The control panel opens if you swipe from right or tap the icon in the upper right corner of the user interface.
description.Hidden: The control panel is removed from the user interface.

attributes.description: This setting allows you to remove the control panel (including the device settings panel) from the user interface. Refer to the UserInterface SettingsMenu Mode if you just want to protect the device settings with a password.

description.Auto: The control panel opens if you swipe from right or tap the icon in the upper right corner of the user interface.
description.Hidden: The control panel is removed from the user interface.

attributes.description: You can configure the device to make a sound effect, for example, when someone connects a laptop or mobile through Proximity. The keyboard click sound effect when typing text is not affected by this setting (refer to the UserInterface Keytones Mode setting).

description.Off: There are no sound effects.
description.On: The sound effects are switched on.

attributes.description: Change the theme on the user interface. Note, this config may change or be replaced in the future.

description.Auto: Use the default settings, letting the system decide what is best.

attributes.description: Decide what to do with the wallpaper if the screen and wallpaper doesn't have the same aspect ratio.

description.Crop: Scales up the wallpaper so that it fills the entire screen. The wallpaper aspect ratio is kept unchanged, so the top/bottom or left/right side of the image will be cut off as needed.
description.Fit: Scales the wallpaper up or down so that the complete image fits on the screen. The wallpaper aspect ratio is kept unchanged, and black bars are added to the top/bottom (letterboxing) or the sides (pillarboxing) to fill the screen.
description.Stretch: Stretch the wallpaper until it fills the entire screen. Changes the wallpaper aspect ratio if needed.

attributes.description: Activity indicators let you see who is drawing and annotating in a call. The avatars of the participants or the initials of the device are displayed when someone is interacting with the whiteboard, so you can follow who is drawing or annotating. Applies only to cloud-registered devices.

description.Off: Disables activity indicators.
description.On: Enables activity indicators.

attributes.description: Choose whether to hide the option to delete a whiteboard from the user interface - both in the whiteboard app and the files app. This does not disable deleting whiteboards as such, it only removes the button from the UI. You can still use the xAPI (Files Delete command).

description.Auto: Shows the delete button on the user interface.
description.Hidden: Removes the delete button from the user interface.

attributes.description: Choose whether to hide the option to share an existing whiteboard in call from the user interface (the Call app and the Whiteboard app). This does not stop whiteboard being shared in call from another device, and does not disable sharing whiteboard in call from the API.

description.Auto: Show the Share button (share in call option) on the UI.
description.Hidden: Remove the Share button (share in call option) from the UI. Hence remove the option to share a whiteboard in call from the UI.

attributes.description: The LDAP filter is used to determine which users should be granted administrator privileges. You always have to set either an LDAP Admin Group or an LDAP Admin Filter. An LDAP Admin Filter takes precedence, so if the UserManagement LDAP Admin Filter is set, the UserManagement LDAP Admin Group setting is ignored.

Members of this group will be given administrator access. This setting is a shorthand for saying (memberOf:1.2.840.113556.1.4.1941:=<group name>). You must always set either an LDAP Admin Group or an LDAP Admin Filter. An LDAP Admin Filter takes precedence, so if the UserManagement LDAP Admin Filter is set, the UserManagement LDAP Admin Group setting is ignored.
The attribute used to map to the provided username. If not set, sAMAccountName is used.
The distinguishing name of the entry at which to start a search (base).

Look up a user's full DN (distinguishing name) by logging in to the LDAP server using these credentials and use the DN for group look-up.  The look-up is based on matching the user's login name to the value of the "Attribute" configuration item. Refer to the UserManagement LDAP MemberAttribute setting.
The password associated with the user defined in the UserManagement LDAP BindDN setting. This password is not sent to the Webex cloud, and it cannot be provisioned from the cloud.
Define how to secure the communication between the device and the LDAP server. You can override the port number by using the UserManagement LDAP Server Port setting.

description.LDAPS: Connect to the LDAP server on port 636 over TLS (Transport Layer Security).
description.None: Connect to the LDAP server on port 389 with no encryption.
description.STARTTLS: Connect to the LDAP server on port 389, then send a STARTTLS command to upgrade to an encrypted connection (TLS).

attributes.description: When checking the user's group membership, use this group attribute. If not set, use memberUid.
Set the lowest version of the TLS (Transport Layer Security) protocol that is allowed for LDAP.

The device supports the use of an LDAP (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol) server as a central place to store and validate usernames and passwords. Use this setting to configure whether or not to use LDAP authentication. Our implementation is tested for the Microsoft Active Directory (AD) service. If you switch on LDAP Mode, make sure to configure the other UserManagement LDAP settings to suit your setup. Here is a few examples. Example 1: - UserManagement LDAP Mode: On - UserManagement LDAP Address: "192.0.2.20" - UserManagement LDAP BaseDN: "DC=company, DC=com" - UserManagement LDAP Admin Group: "CN=admin group, OU=company groups, DC=company, DC=com" Example 2: - UserManagement LDAP Mode: On - UserManagement LDAP Address: "192.0.2.20" - UserManagement LDAP BaseDN: "DC=company, DC=com" - UserManagement LDAP Admin Filter: "(|(memberof=CN=admin group, OU=company groups, DC=company, DC=com)(sAMAccountName=username))"

description.Off: LDAP authentication is not allowed.
description.On: LDAP authentication is allowed.

attributes.description: Set the IP address or hostname of the LDAP server.
Set the port to connect to the LDAP server on. If set to 0, use the default for the selected protocol (see the UserManagement LDAP Encryption setting).

When the device connects to an LDAP server, the server will identify itself to the device by presenting its certificate. Use this setting to determine whether or not the device will verify the server certificate.

description.Off: The device will not verify the LDAP server's certificate.
description.On: The device must verify that the LDAP server's certificate is signed by a trusted Certificate Authority (CA). The CA must be on the list of trusted CAs that are uploaded to the device in advance. Use the device's web interface to manage the list of trusted CAs (see more details in the administrator guide).

attributes.description: When signing in to the device as a local user, the password must follow the rules set by the UserManagement PasswordPolicy settings. These settings replace the "systemtools securitysetting" command that was available in software versions older than CE9.10. A new password rule will not apply to existing passwords but will take effect on the next password change. This setting specifies the minimum number of numerical characters (0..9) in the password.

When signing in to the device as a local user, the password must follow the rules set by the UserManagement PasswordPolicy settings. These settings replace the "systemtools securitysetting" command that was available in software versions older than CE9.10. A new password rule will not apply to existing passwords but will take effect on the next password change. This setting specifies the minimum password strength using entropy calculation.

When signing in to the device as a local user, the password must follow the rules set by the UserManagement PasswordPolicy settings. These settings replace the "systemtools securitysetting" command that was available in software versions older than CE9.10. A new password rule will not apply to existing passwords but will take effect on the next password change. This setting specifies the minimum number of characters in the password.

When signing in to the device as a local user, the password must follow the rules set by the UserManagement PasswordPolicy settings. These settings replace the "systemtools securitysetting" command that was available in software versions older than CE9.10. A new password rule will not apply to existing passwords but will take effect on the next password change. This setting specifies the minimum number of lower-case letters in the password.

When signing in to the device as a local user, the password must follow the rules set by the UserManagement PasswordPolicy settings. These settings replace the "systemtools securitysetting" command that was available in software versions older than CE9.10. A new password rule will not apply to existing passwords but will take effect on the next password change. This setting specifies the minimum number of special characters in the password.

When signing in to the device as a local user, the password must follow the rules set by the UserManagement PasswordPolicy settings. These settings replace the "systemtools securitysetting" command that was available in software versions older than CE9.10. A new password rule will not apply to existing passwords but will take effect on the next password change. This setting specifies the minimum number of upper-case letters in the password.

When signing in to the device as a local user, the password must follow the rules set by the UserManagement PasswordPolicy settings. These settings replace the "systemtools securitysetting" command that was available in software versions older than CE9.10. A new password rule will not apply to existing passwords but will take effect on the next password change. This setting specifies the maximum number of days before a password becomes invalid.

When signing in to the device as a local user, the password must follow the rules set by the UserManagement PasswordPolicy settings. These settings replace the "systemtools securitysetting" command that was available in software versions older than CE9.10. A new password rule will not apply to existing passwords but will take effect on the next password change. This setting specifies the reuse limit (n), which means that a user cannot change to either of their previous n passwords.
Select which video layout family to use locally.

description.Auto: The default layout family, as given in the layout database provided by the device, will be used as the local layout.
description.Equal: The Grid layout family will be used as the local layout. Participants are shown in a grid of equal sized videos. If there is shared content it will appear beside the grid.
description.Overlay: Not applicable in this software release.
description.Prominent_L: The Prominent layout family will be used as the local layout. The active speaker is shown in the upper left part of the screen, and other participants are ranged across the bottom and beside on the right.
description.Single: The Focus layout family will be used as the local layout. The active speaker, or the presentation if present, will be shown in full screen. The other participants are not shown. Transitions between active speakers are voice switched.

attributes.description: Select which video layout family to switch to by default locally, when content sharing starts. This configuration is applicable only to single-screen endpoints and does not affect dual-screen endpoints.

description.Auto: The default layout family, as given in the layout database provided by the device, will be used as the local layout.
description.Equal: The Grid layout family will be used as the local layout. Participants are shown in a grid of equal sized videos. Shared content will appear beside the grid.
description.Overlay: Not applicable in this software release.
description.Prominent_L: The Prominent layout family will be used as the local layout. Content is shown in the upper left part of the screen, and participants are ranged across the bottom and beside on the right.
description.Single: The Focus layout family will be used as the local layout. The shared content will be shown in full screen. Participants are not shown.

attributes.description: Define the default input source for main video in calls. The main video is played on this source when you switch on or restart the video device. Use the Video Input SetMainVideoSource command to change to another source while the device is running.

Turn on discovery beacon support. The discovery beacon makes AirPlay deployment easier in environments where the video device and the iPhone, iPad, or Mac are not guaranteed to be on the same broadcast domain (VLAN or subnet). This is typically the case in enterprise network set ups. Beacon discovery requires BluetoothÂ®. On Desk Series, Board Pro, Board Pro G2, Room Bar, and Room Bar Pro, you must enable Bluetooth with the dedicated Bluetooth Allowed and Bluetooth Enabled settings. On devices that don't have dedicated Bluetooth settings, Bluetooth is automatically enabled when you turn on the discovery beacon. This setting isn't on the first generation of Board (non S-series) because these devices don't support AirPlay.

description.Auto: The AirPlay beacon is activated, and the device is discoverable. Typically used in enterprise network setups.
description.Off: The AirPlay beacon is deactivated, and the device will not be discoverable through the beacon service. Typically used in home network set ups.

attributes.description: Insert the name of the network that the Apple device must connect to. If not set, the Video Input AirPlay DiscoveryInstructions ShowNetworkInfo setting will display the name defined in the network itself. This setting isn't on the first generation of Board (non S-series) because these devices don't support AirPlay.

Decide whether to show the name of the network that the Apple device must connect to on the AirPlay information screen (Curtain) on the video device. The network name is either defined in the network itself, or explicitly set in the Video Input AirPlay DiscoveryInstructions NetworkName setting. The latter take precedence. This setting isn't on the first generation of Board (non S-series) because these devices don't support AirPlay.

description.False: Don't display the network name on the AirPlay information screen.
description.True: Display the network name on the AirPlay information screen.

attributes.description: All devices, except the first generation of Board (non S-series), support AirPlay. With AirPlay users can wirelessly connect their iPhone, iPad, or Mac to share their screen, collaborate, and playback audio and video content. Use this setting to activate AirPlay on a device. Once activated, users can disable and re-enable AirPlay themselves from the device's Settings menu if using a personal mode device. This is not possible for shared devices.

description.Off: AirPlay is deactivated on the device.
description.On: AirPlay is activated on the device.

attributes.description: Define the password that must be used for AirPlay pairing when the Video Input AirPlay Security setting is set to Password. This setting isn't on the first generation of Board (non S-series) because these devices don't support AirPlay.
Defines if the content presented through AirPlay is automatically shared.

Define the type of authentication to use when pairing an iPhone, iPad, or Mac to the device (AirPlay pairing). This setting isn't on the first generation of Board (non S-series) because these devices don't support AirPlay.

description.Password: The device will require a password for AirPlay pairing. You must define the password in the Video Input AirPlay Password setting. If you don't define a password, the device will revert to default and request a PIN.
description.PinAlways: The device will request a PIN at every AirPlay pairing (except if reconnecting within 30 seconds after disconnecting).
description.PinFirstTime: The device will request a PIN at the first AirPlay pairing. After the first time, the successfully paired device will be remembered.

attributes.description: This setting applies only when connecting a Precision 60, PTZ-12, or PTZ 4K camera as a second or third camera to the device. When connecting an extra camera to a device, several settings must be changed accordingly. This can be done manually, one setting at a time, or automatically when the device detects that a camera is connected. In automatic mode these settings will be applied (n is the connector that the camera is connected to). Video Input Connector [n] CameraControl CameraId: n Video Input Connector [n] CameraControl Mode: On Video Input Connector [n] InputSourceType: camera Video Input Connector [n] PresentationSelection: Manual Video Input Connector [n] Quality: Motion If the Cameras Camera [n] AssignedSerialNumber setting has been applied, the settings above will not be pushed even if the CameraConfigMode is set to Auto. In general, this happens when EDID information is not available, and thereby prevents the device from detecting that a camera is connected. In this case the device issues a warning. Also, don't use Auto mode if the Cameras Camera n DetectedConnector status doesn't correspond to the input connector number (n). Example: If camera 2 is connected to HDMI [2], then only use Auto mode if the Cameras Camera 2 DetectedConnector status returns 2. If these numbers don't match, you must use the Cameras Camera [n] AssignedSerialNumber setting instead.

description.Auto: The settings above will be pushed automatically once the device detects that the camera is connected.
description.Manual: You must configure the settings manually, one by one, when connecting a camera.

attributes.description: The camera ID is a unique identifier of the camera that is connected to this video input. For devices with more than one camera, you can see the currently assigned IDs in the Cameras Camera status.
The camera ID is a unique identifier of the camera that is connected to this video input. For devices with more than one camera, you can see the currently assigned IDs in the Cameras Camera status.
The camera ID is a unique identifier of the camera that is connected to this video input. For devices with more than one camera, you can see the currently assigned IDs in the Cameras Camera status.
The camera ID is a unique identifier of the camera that is connected to this video input. For devices with more than one camera, you can see the currently assigned IDs in the Cameras Camera status.
Define whether the camera on this video input connector can be controlled or not. Some connectors cannot be controlled (Off is the only available value).

description.Off: Disable camera control.
description.On: Enable camera control.

attributes.description: Define whether the camera on this video input connector can be controlled or not. Some connectors cannot be controlled (Off is the only available value).

description.Off: Disable camera control.
description.On: Enable camera control.

attributes.description: Define whether the camera on this video input connector can be controlled or not. Some connectors cannot be controlled (Off is the only available value).

description.Off: Disable camera control.
description.On: Enable camera control.

attributes.description: The video input (HDMI) supports Consumer Electronics Control (CEC). When this setting is enabled, information about the connected device (for example device type and device name) is available in the video device status (Video Input Connector [n] ConnectedDevice CEC [n]), provided that the connected device also supports CEC. If you have Quad Camera, do not switch off CEC on that connector because then there will be no sound on the speakers on the camera. CEC is required for HDMI ARC (Audio Return Channel), which is the channel used for sending audio from the video device to the camera.

description.Off: CEC is disabled.
description.On: CEC is enabled.

attributes.description: One of the video device's HDMI inputs can be configured to support HDCP protected content (High-bandwidth Digital Content Protection, version 1.4). This allows customers to re-purpose a video device's screen by connecting devices such as a DVD player, Google ChromeCast, AppleTV, or an HDTV decoder. This type of content cannot be shared while in a call. When the input connector is set up to support HDCP, the following restrictions apply: You can't share any content from this input while in a call. However, you can share both HDCP protected content and non-protected content locally. You can't take web snapshots of this source. To be able to show HDCP protected content on the device's screen, also ensure that the Video Output Connector [n] HDCPPolicy configuration is set correctly and that the screen itself supports HDCP.

description.Off: The video input doesn't support HDCP protected content; it supports only non-protected content.

attributes.description: Select which type of input source is connected to the video input. If the device has an integrated camera, Connector 1 refers to the integrated camera.

description.camera: Use this when a camera is connected to the video input.

attributes.description: Select which type of input source is connected to the video input. If the device has an integrated camera, Connector 1 refers to the integrated camera.

description.PC: Use this when a computer is connected to the video input.
description.camera: Use this when a camera is connected to the video input.
description.document_camera: Use this when a document camera is connected to the video input.
description.mediaplayer: Use this when a media player is connected to the video input.
description.other: Use this when the other options do not match.
description.whiteboard: Use this when a whiteboard camera is connected to the video input.

attributes.default: [1]: camera; [2]: camera; [3]: PC; [4]: camera; [5]: PC; [6]: camera; [7]: PC; [8]: camera; [9]: PC; [10]: camera; [11]: PC; [12]: camera; [13]: PC; [14]: camera; [15]: PC; [16]: camera; [17]: PC;
attributes.description: Select which type of input source is connected to the video input. If the device has an integrated camera, Connector 1 refers to the integrated camera.

description.PC: Use this when a computer is connected to the video input.
description.camera: Use this when a camera is connected to the video input.
description.document_camera: Use this when a document camera is connected to the video input.
description.mediaplayer: Use this when a media player is connected to the video input.
description.other: Use this when the other options do not match.
description.whiteboard: Use this when a whiteboard camera is connected to the video input.

attributes.description: Set the preferred maximum resolution for a video input. Any content shared on this input will have this resolution and framerate, or lower. By setting a MaxResolution you can avoid unnecessary upscaling and achieve the exact resolution you intend. For example, on video inputs that support 4K, you can limit the preferred resolution to avoid automatic 4K upscaling.

Set the preferred maximum resolution for a video input. Any content shared on this input will have this resolution and framerate, or lower. By setting a MaxResolution you can avoid unnecessary upscaling and achieve the exact resolution you intend. For example, on video inputs that support 4K, you can limit the preferred resolution to avoid automatic 4K upscaling.
Define a name for the video input connector.

attributes.default: [1]: Camera 1; [2]: Camera 2; [3]: Camera 2; [4]: Camera 2; [5]: Camera 2; [6]: Camera 2; [7]: Camera 2; [8]: Camera 2; [9]: Camera 2;
attributes.description: Define a name for the video input connector.

attributes.default: [1]: Camera; [2]: PC 1 (HDMI); [3]: PC 1 (HDMI); [4]: PC 1 (HDMI); [5]: PC 1 (HDMI); [6]: PC 1 (HDMI); [7]: PC 1 (HDMI); [8]: PC 1 (HDMI); [9]: PC 1 (HDMI); [10]: PC 1 (HDMI);
attributes.description: Define a name for the video input connector.

Define the preferred screen resolution and refresh rate that the video device advertises to the connected input sources (for example a laptop). The logic for selection of the resolution on the source side will choose this resolution and refresh rate automatically, unless it is overridden manually by the source device (for example the laptop's display configuration software). Note that larger formats than 1920_1080_60 use much more data, and requires a presentation cable (or adapter) that is qualified for at least HDMI 1.4b data rates.

description.1920_1080_60: The resolution is 1920 x 1080, and the refresh rate is 60 Hz.

attributes.description: Define the preferred screen resolution and refresh rate that the video device advertises to the connected input sources (for example a laptop). The logic for selection of the resolution on the source side will choose this resolution and refresh rate automatically, unless it is overridden manually by the source device (for example the laptop's display configuration software). Note that larger formats than 1920_1080_60 use much more data, and requires a presentation cable (or adapter) that is qualified for at least HDMI 1.4b data rates.

description.1920_1080_60: The resolution is 1920 x 1080, and the refresh rate is 60 Hz.
description.2560_1080_60: The resolution is 2560 x 1080, and the refresh rate is 60 Hz.
description.2560_1440_60: The resolution is 2560 x 1440, and the refresh rate is 60 Hz.
description.2880_1200_60: The resolution is 2880 x 1200, and the refresh rate is 60 Hz.
description.3440_1440_30: The resolution is 3440 x 1440, and the refresh rate is 30 Hz.
description.3840_1600_30: The resolution is 3840 x 1600, and the refresh rate is 30 Hz.
description.3840_1620_30: The resolution is 3840 x 1620, and the refresh rate is 30 Hz
description.3840_2160_30: The resolution is 3840 x 2160, and the refresh rate is 30 Hz.

attributes.description: Define how the video device will behave when you connect a presentation source to the video input. If the device is in standby mode, it will wake up when you connect a presentation source. Sharing the presentation with the far end requires additional action (select Share on the user interface) except when this setting is set to AutoShare. For devices with more than one camera: Any input source can be used as a presentation source; usually, the main camera will not be used as a presentation source. For devices with an integrated camera: The integrated camera is not available as a presentation source.

description.AutoShare: While in a call, the content on the video input will automatically be presented to the far end as well as on the local screen when you connect the cable, or when the source is activated otherwise (for example when a connected computer wakes up from sleep mode). You do not have to select Share on the user interface. If a presentation source is already connected when you make or answer a call, you have to manually select Share on the user interface.
description.Desktop: The content on the video input will be presented on the screen when you connect the cable, or when the source is activated otherwise (for example when a connected computer wakes up from sleep mode). This applies both when idle and in a call. Also, the content on the video input will stay on the screen when you leave the call, provided that it was the active input at the time of leaving.
description.Manual: The content on the video input will not be presented on the screen until you select Share from the user interface.
description.OnConnect: The content on the video input will be presented on screen when you connect the cable, or when the source is activated otherwise (for example when a connected computer wakes up from sleep mode). Otherwise, the behavior is the same as in manual mode.

attributes.description: When encoding and transmitting video there is a trade-off between high resolution and high frame rate. For some video sources it is more important to transmit high frame rate than high resolution and vice versa. This setting specifies whether to give priority to high frame rate or to high resolution. If a Quad Camera, SpeakerTrack 60 camera, or Precision 60 camera is detected by the device this setting is automatically set to Motion. If a user changes this setting manually, it will be set back to Motion after a restart or a camera reconnect.

description.Auto: As a starting point Auto resolves to Sharpness and the video stream will be encoded accordingly. The device will continuously analyze the incoming video stream, and if motion is detected it will automatically change to encoding for Motion.
description.Motion: Gives the highest possible frame rate. Used when there is a need for higher frame rates, typically when there is motion in the picture.
description.Sharpness: Gives the highest possible resolution. Used when you want the highest quality of detailed images and graphics.

attributes.description: The devices connected to the video input should follow the rules for RGB video quantization range defined in CTA-861. Unfortunately some devices do not follow the standard and this configuration may be used to override the settings to get a perfect image with any source.

description.Auto: RGB quantization range is automatically selected based on video format according to CTA-861-F. CE video formats will use limited quantization range levels. IT video formats will use full quantization range levels.
description.Full: Full quantization range. The R, G, B quantization range includes all code values (0 - 255). This is defined in CTA-861-F.
description.Limited: Limited Quantization Range. R, G, B quantization range that excludes some code values at the extremes (16 - 235). This is defined in CTA-861-F.

attributes.description: Define the visibility of the video input connector in the menus and buttons on the user interface. For devices with an integrated camera: Connector 1 is the device's integrated camera and is not available as a presentation source.

description.Never: The input source is not expected to be used as a presentation source, and will not show up on the user interface.

attributes.description: Define the visibility of the video input connector in the menus and buttons on the user interface. For devices with an integrated camera: Connector 1 is the device's integrated camera and is not available as a presentation source.

description.Always: The menu selection for the video input connector will always be visible on the user interface.
description.IfSignal: Yhe menu selection for the video input connector will only be visible when something is connected to the video input.
description.Never: The input source is not expected to be used as a presentation source, and will not show up on the user interface.

attributes.default: [1]: Never; [2]: IfSignal; [3]: IfSignal; [4]: IfSignal; [5]: IfSignal; [6]: IfSignal; [7]: IfSignal; [8]: IfSignal; [9]: IfSignal; [10]: IfSignal;
attributes.description: Define the visibility of the video input connector in the menus and buttons on the user interface. For devices with an integrated camera: Connector 1 is the device's integrated camera and is not available as a presentation source.

description.IfSignal: Yhe menu selection for the video input connector will only be visible when something is connected to the video input.
description.Never: The input source is not expected to be used as a presentation source, and will not show up on the user interface.

attributes.default: [1]: Never; [2]: IfSignal; [3]: IfSignal; [4]: IfSignal; [5]: IfSignal; [6]: IfSignal; [7]: IfSignal; [8]: IfSignal; [9]: IfSignal;
attributes.description: Define the visibility of the video input connector in the menus and buttons on the user interface. For devices with an integrated camera: Connector 1 is the device's integrated camera and is not available as a presentation source.

description.Always: The menu selection for the video input connector will always be visible on the user interface.
description.IfSignal: Yhe menu selection for the video input connector will only be visible when something is connected to the video input.
description.Never: The input source is not expected to be used as a presentation source, and will not show up on the user interface.

attributes.description: The camera ID is a unique identifier of the camera that is connected to this video input. For devices with more than one camera, you can see the currently assigned IDs in the Cameras Camera status.
The camera ID is a unique identifier of the camera that is connected to this video input. For devices with more than one camera, you can see the currently assigned IDs in the Cameras Camera status.

attributes.description: Define whether the camera on this video input connector can be controlled or not. Some connectors cannot be controlled (Off is the only available value).

description.Off: Disable camera control.
description.On: Enable camera control.

attributes.description: The video input (HDMI) supports Consumer Electronics Control (CEC). When this setting is enabled, information about the connected device (for example device type and device name) is available in the video device status (Video Input Connector [n] ConnectedDevice CEC [n]), provided that the connected device also supports CEC. If you have Quad Camera, do not switch off CEC on that connector because then there will be no sound on the speakers on the camera. CEC is required for HDMI ARC (Audio Return Channel), which is the channel used for sending audio from the video device to the camera.

description.Off: CEC is disabled.
description.On: CEC is enabled.

attributes.description: One of the video device's HDMI inputs can be configured to support HDCP protected content (High-bandwidth Digital Content Protection, version 1.4). This allows customers to re-purpose a video device's screen by connecting devices such as a DVD player, Google ChromeCast, AppleTV, or an HDTV decoder. This type of content cannot be shared while in a call. When the input connector is set up to support HDCP, the following restrictions apply: You can't share any content from this input while in a call. However, you can share both HDCP protected content and non-protected content locally. You can't take web snapshots of this source. To be able to show HDCP protected content on the device's screen, also ensure that the Video Output Connector [n] HDCPPolicy configuration is set correctly and that the screen itself supports HDCP.

description.Off: The video input doesn't support HDCP protected content; it supports only non-protected content.

attributes.description: Select which type of input source is connected to the video input. If the device has an integrated camera, Connector 1 refers to the integrated camera.

description.PC: Use this when a computer is connected to the video input.
description.camera: Use this when a camera is connected to the video input.
description.document_camera: Use this when a document camera is connected to the video input.
description.mediaplayer: Use this when a media player is connected to the video input.
description.other: Use this when the other options do not match.
description.whiteboard: Use this when a whiteboard camera is connected to the video input.

attributes.description: Set the preferred maximum resolution for a video input. Any content shared on this input will have this resolution and framerate, or lower. By setting a MaxResolution you can avoid unnecessary upscaling and achieve the exact resolution you intend. For example, on video inputs that support 4K, you can limit the preferred resolution to avoid automatic 4K upscaling.

Set the preferred maximum resolution for a video input. Any content shared on this input will have this resolution and framerate, or lower. By setting a MaxResolution you can avoid unnecessary upscaling and achieve the exact resolution you intend. For example, on video inputs that support 4K, you can limit the preferred resolution to avoid automatic 4K upscaling.

For example, on video inputs that support 4K, you can limit the preferred resolution to avoid automatic 4K upscaling.

Define the preferred screen resolution and refresh rate that the video device advertises to the connected input sources (for example a laptop). The logic for selection of the resolution on the source side will choose this resolution and refresh rate automatically, unless it is overridden manually by the source device (for example the laptop's display configuration software). Note that larger formats than 1920_1080_60 use much more data, and requires a presentation cable (or adapter) that is qualified for at least HDMI 1.4b data rates.

description.1920_1080_60: The resolution is 1920 x 1080, and the refresh rate is 60 Hz.

attributes.description: Define how the video device will behave when you connect a presentation source to the video input. If the device is in standby mode, it will wake up when you connect a presentation source. Sharing the presentation with the far end requires additional action (select Share on the user interface) except when this setting is set to AutoShare. For devices with more than one camera: Any input source can be used as a presentation source; usually, the main camera will not be used as a presentation source. For devices with an integrated camera: The integrated camera is not available as a presentation source.

description.AutoShare: While in a call, the content on the video input will automatically be presented to the far end as well as on the local screen when you connect the cable, or when the source is activated otherwise (for example when a connected computer wakes up from sleep mode). You do not have to select Share on the user interface. If a presentation source is already connected when you make or answer a call, you have to manually select Share on the user interface.
description.Desktop: The content on the video input will be presented on the screen when you connect the cable, or when the source is activated otherwise (for example when a connected computer wakes up from sleep mode). This applies both when idle and in a call. Also, the content on the video input will stay on the screen when you leave the call, provided that it was the active input at the time of leaving.
description.Manual: The content on the video input will not be presented on the screen until you select Share from the user interface.
description.OnConnect: The content on the video input will be presented on screen when you connect the cable, or when the source is activated otherwise (for example when a connected computer wakes up from sleep mode). Otherwise, the behavior is the same as in manual mode.

attributes.description: When encoding and transmitting video there is a trade-off between high resolution and high frame rate. For some video sources it is more important to transmit high frame rate than high resolution and vice versa. This setting specifies whether to give priority to high frame rate or to high resolution. If a Quad Camera, SpeakerTrack 60 camera, or Precision 60 camera is detected by the device this setting is automatically set to Motion. If a user changes this setting manually, it will be set back to Motion after a restart or a camera reconnect.

description.Auto: As a starting point Auto resolves to Sharpness and the video stream will be encoded accordingly. The device will continuously analyze the incoming video stream, and if motion is detected it will automatically change to encoding for Motion.
description.Motion: Gives the highest possible frame rate. Used when there is a need for higher frame rates, typically when there is motion in the picture.
description.Sharpness: Gives the highest possible resolution. Used when you want the highest quality of detailed images and graphics.

attributes.description: The devices connected to the video input should follow the rules for RGB video quantization range defined in CTA-861. Unfortunately some devices do not follow the standard and this configuration may be used to override the settings to get a perfect image with any source.

description.Auto: RGB quantization range is automatically selected based on video format according to CTA-861-F. CE video formats will use limited quantization range levels. IT video formats will use full quantization range levels.
description.Full: Full quantization range. The R, G, B quantization range includes all code values (0 - 255). This is defined in CTA-861-F.
description.Limited: Limited Quantization Range. R, G, B quantization range that excludes some code values at the extremes (16 - 235). This is defined in CTA-861-F.

attributes.description: Define the visibility of the video input connector in the menus and buttons on the user interface. For devices with an integrated camera: Connector 1 is the device's integrated camera and is not available as a presentation source.

description.Always: The menu selection for the video input connector will always be visible on the user interface.
description.IfSignal: Yhe menu selection for the video input connector will only be visible when something is connected to the video input.
description.Never: The input source is not expected to be used as a presentation source, and will not show up on the user interface.
